panels.description:
Number of active controllers in the cluster.

This should always be `1`.

If the controller broker goes down, another broker will be elected as controller.
panels.title: Active Controllers

panels.description:
Number of Brokers Online.

This should be `3`.

We can live with 1 broker going down.
panels.title: Brokers Online

panels.description: Partitions that are online
panels.title: Online Partitions

panels.description:
Number of under-replicated partitions (| ISR | < | all replicas |).

This measurement gives a count of the number of partitions for which the broker is the leader replica, where the follower replicas are not caught up.

Generally, a steady number of under-replicated partitions ( > 0), indicates that a broker is offline. 

If the number of under replicated partitions is fluctuating, this indicates a performance issue within the cluster.
panels.title: Under Replicated Partitions

panels.description:
Number of partitions under min insync replicas.

Note, when creating a topic we specified the minimum number of in-sync replicas (`2`).

By default, each partition should have 3 ISR (each replica will exist on `broker 501`, `broker 502`, `broker 503`). 

We can therefore tolerate one broker / ISR replica going down before producers/consumers wont be able to publish/pull from kafka.
panels.title: Under Min ISR Partitions

panels.description:
Number of partitions that dont have an active leader and are hence not writable or readable.

Indicative that a broker may be down!
panels.title: Offline Partitions Count

panels.description: Unclean leader election rate
panels.title: Unclean Leader Election Rate

panels.description:
Errors that appear in the kafka docker logs will show here. 

Some errors are not as serious as others... i.e. there are `RETRIABLE` errors that should resolve themselves depending on our producer/consumers retry rate.

See: https://kafka.apache.org/20/protocol.html#protocol_error_codes.

`BROKER_NOT_AVAILABLE  |  REPLICA_NOT_AVAILABLE` - These errors are indicators that a broker might not be available. Please go and ensure all brokers are up and running. Note, we some redundancy in that we can support one broker going down from the broker. If we lost another broker (total: 2) we would suffer data-loss as each topic is expected to have at least 2 copies across the cluster. **Severity: high**

`MEMBER_ID_REQUIRED` - consumers need to have an ID before joining a group. All consumers within MRP have a group ID. Thus,  this error should not appear. Regardless, this is more an issue with the consumer logic than broker. **Severity**: **low**

`NOT_CONTROLLER` - This is not the correct controller for this cluster. It may appear on topic creation if not connected to the controller broker.  **Severity: low**

`REBALANCE_IN_PROGRESS` - Whenever a consumer dies/leaves a group, kafka will trigger a **rebalance** which will redistribute partitions to another consumer. Rebalances happen quite regularly in Kafka - deeper look needed if there are 10's of rebalances daily  (and no production deploys).  **Severity: low** (*if there are less than 10 rebalances happening daily*) ... **Severity: high** (*if kafka logs are being spammed with rebalance messages*)

`UNKNOWN*` - Can ignore  this group of errors for now (*red-herrings*) **Severity: low**

`UNKNOWN_TOPIC_OR_PARTITION`. This exception occurs when a producer or consumer  is trying to send/read from a topic/partition that does not exist. Please go and check that the topic exists in the cluster. A ticket should've been raised to create said topic before any changes that use this topic made it to prod. **Severity: high**
panels.title: Errors

panels.description: CPU usage of our kafka containers
panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description:
Shows the size **on disk** that each topic uses.

If a topic's log size is growing aggressively, modify the `retention.ms` time of the topic.

We have ~ `250GB` of disk space per broker. If disk utilization creeps over 200GB, look to purge.
panels.title: Log size per Topic

panels.description: : The number of in-sync replicas (ISRs) for a particular partition should remain fairly static, the only exceptions are when you are expanding your broker cluster or removing partitions. In order to maintain high availability, a healthy Kafka cluster requires a minimum number of ISRs for failover. A replica could be removed from the ISR pool for a couple of reasons: it is too far behind the leaders offset (user-configurable by setting the replica.lag.max.messages configuration parameter), or it has not contacted the leader for some time (configurable with the replica.socket.timeout.ms parameter). No matter the reason, an increase in IsrShrinksPerSec without a corresponding increase in IsrExpandsPerSec shortly thereafter is cause for concern and requires user intervention.The Kafka documentation provides a wealth of information on the user-configurable parameters for brokers.
panels.title: IsrShrinks per Sec

panels.description: : The number of in-sync replicas (ISRs) for a particular partition should remain fairly static, the only exceptions are when you are expanding your broker cluster or removing partitions. In order to maintain high availability, a healthy Kafka cluster requires a minimum number of ISRs for failover. A replica could be removed from the ISR pool for a couple of reasons: it is too far behind the leaders offset (user-configurable by setting the replica.lag.max.messages configuration parameter), or it has not contacted the leader for some time (configurable with the replica.socket.timeout.ms parameter). No matter the reason, an increase in IsrShrinksPerSec without a corresponding increase in IsrExpandsPerSec shortly thereafter is cause for concern and requires user intervention.The Kafka documentation provides a wealth of information on the user-configurable parameters for brokers.
panels.title: IsrExpands per Sec
